case_name: Partnership firm of Nandlal Bhimjibhai, Tarachand Bhimjibhai and Rajnikant Bhimjibhai v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1058 of 1965 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1058 of 1965. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated March 14/15, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 56 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated March 14/15, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 56 of 1960.

facts.text: The assessee is a partnership firm constituted under a Deed of Partnership dated March 19, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a partnership firm constituted under a Deed of Partnership dated March 19, 1950.

facts.text: Partners are three brothers: Nandlal Bhimjibhai, Tarachand Bhimjibhai and Rajnikant Bhimjibhai, each having an equal 1/3rd share.

anchor.surface_text: The partners are three brothers- Nandlal Bhimjibhai,Tarachand Bhimjibhai andRajnikant Bhimjibhai, each one having an equal 1/3rd sharein he partnership firm.

facts.text: Prior to November 1949, the three partners carried on business with eight others as Rajnikant Vitheldas Co.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to November, 1949, the threepartners of the assessee-firm in partnership with eight others carried on business in Bombay and other places in the name and style of Rajnikant Vitheldas Co.

facts.text: In the larger firm, each of the three brothers had an equal two annas share, others ten annas.

anchor.surface_text: In that larger firm, each one of the three brothers had an equal two annas share each, the other eight partners having the remaining ten anna share.

facts.text: Larger partnership Rajnikant Vitheldas Co. dissolved on October 31, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The larger partnership of Rajnikant Vitheldas Co. was dissolved on October 31, 1949

facts.text: On dissolution, business of two branches at Nagpur allotted to the three brothers.

anchor.surface_text: and on its dissolution the business of the two branches thereof at Nagpur was allotted to the three brothers,

facts.text: Three brothers constituted new firm (assessee) as from November 1, 1949 under deed executed March 19, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: who thereupon as from November 1, 1949 constituted themselves into a new firm, viz., the assessee-firm under the deed of partnership executed on March 19, 1950.

facts.text: Deed recites three brothers agreed to continue business of two Nagpur branches.

anchor.surface_text: This document recites that the three brothers have agreed to continue the business of the two branches at Nagpur

facts.text: Capital of partnership Rs. 2,40,000 divided into 15 shares of Rs. 16,000 each.

anchor.surface_text: The capital of the partnership shall be Rs. 2,40,000. -  Rupees two lacs forty thousand  divided into 15 shares of Rs. 16,000/- each.

facts.text: Each partner allotted equal shares: five shares each.

anchor.surface_text: The partners hereby agree that the shares allotted to different partners will be equal i.e., each partner will get five shares.

facts.text: Net profit or loss divided amongst all partners.

anchor.surface_text: After meeting all expenses, interest and other charges,the resulting net profit or loss shall be ascertained and shall be divided amongst all partners.

facts.text: In case of death or insolvency, surviving partners have right to purchase shares at preceding balance sheet valuation.

anchor.surface_text: In case of death, or insolvency of any partner the surviving partners or such of them as are willing shall have the rights to purchase the shares of such partners at the valuation of the shares in the preceding balance sheet.

facts.text: Retiring partner gives two months written notice, remaining partners purchase shares proportionally at valuation.

anchor.surface_text: In case of any partner desiring to retire from the partnership will have to give a written notice of at least two months to the other partners of his intention to do so. On receipt of such notice, the remaining partner or partners will purchase the share or shares in pro- portion to their holding at the time the valuation in paragraph 13.

facts.text: For assessment year 1951-52, partners applied to ITO for registration under Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, produced deed.

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment year 1951-52, the three partners applied to the Income-tax Officer for registration of the firm under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  hereinafter called the Act . Along with this application, the deed of partnership dated March 19, 1950 was produced.

facts.text: ITO granted registration for AY 1951-52 by order dated March 20, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated March 20, 1956 the Income-tax Officer granted registration under s. 26A of the Act for the assessment year 1951-52.

facts.text: ITO determined firm total income Rs. 87,172 for AY 1951-52, allocated one-third to each partner Rs. 29,057.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day, he determined the total income of the firm at Rs. 87,172/-, and under s. 23 6  of the Act, allocated it between the three partners for tax purposes, each partner getting one-third share of the total income i.e., Rs. 29,0571/.

facts.text: Renewal of registration granted for AY 1952-53 on March 28, 1957 based on same deed.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the same deed, an application was made for the renewal of registration of the firm for the assessment year 1952-53. The renewal was granted- on March 28, 1957.

facts.text: For AY 1953-54, renewal application based on same deed rejected by ITO on March 28, 1958 as no clause specifying individual shares.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1953- 54,the partners again applied for renewal of registration on thebasis of the same deed, but the Income-tax Officer was of theopinion that there was no clause in the deed specifying theindividual shares of each partner as required by s. 26A of the Act. After issuing notices to the three partners and after giving them a hearing, the Income-tax Officer, by his order dated March 28, 1958, rejected the application

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee took the matter in appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner but the appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: Second appeal to Appellate Tribunal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee preferred a second appeal to the appellate Tribunal but that appeal also was dismissed.

facts.text: At instance of assessee, Tribunal referred question of law to High Court under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the assessee the appellate Tribunal referred the following question of law for the determination of the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Act

facts.text: Question: Whether on proper construction of partnership deed dated 19-3-1950, firm for AY 1953-54 specifies individual shares as per s.26A.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on a proper construction of the partnership deed dated 19-3-1950, the firm sought to be registered for the assessment year 1953-54, can be said to have -been constituted under an instrument of partnership specifying the individual shares of the partners as required by section 26A of the Act

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered question in negative by judgment dated March 15, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment -dated March 15, 1961, the High Court answered the question in the negative, holding that renewal of registration under s. 26A of the Act was rightly refused by the Income-tax -authorities.

facts.text: In all applications for registration, three partners shown to share profits equally.

anchor.surface_text: It should also be noticed that in all the applications for registration made by the assessee-firm under s. 26A of the Act the three partners have been shown to share the profits of the partnership firm equally.

facts.text: In books of accounts since November 1, 1949, profits apportioned equally among three partners.

anchor.surface_text: There is also the other circumstance that in the books of accounts for all the years since its commencement from November 1, 1949 right upto date the profits have been apportioned equally mong the three partners

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that partnership deed specifies individual shares of partners in profits as per s.26A, firm entitled to registration for AY 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: Reading the partnership deed as a whole and in the context of the relevant circumstances of the case, we are of the opinion that there was specification of the individual shares of the partners in the profits within the meaning of s. 26A of the Act and the assessee-firm was entitled to registration for the assessment year in question.

facts.text: Capital under cl.3 equal for each partner: 5 shares of Rs.16,000 in total Rs.2,40,000.

anchor.surface_text: It is evident that under cl.  3  of the partnership deed, the capital allotted to each partner is equal, viz., 5 shares of Rs. 16,000/each in a total capital of Rs. 2,40,000/-

facts.text: Clause 10: net profit/loss divided amongst all partners.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  10  states that after meeting all expenses, interest and other charges, the resulting net profit or loss shall be ascertained and shall be divided amongst all partners.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 14/15, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 56 of 1960.
By his order dated March 20, 1956 the Income-tax Officer granted registration under s. 26A of the Act for the assessment year 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment -dated March 15, 1961, the High Court answered the question in the negative, holding that renewal of registration under s. 26A of the Act was rightly refused by the Income-tax -authorities.

concepts.unlisted_description: Procedure in registration of firms requiring instrument specifying individual shares of partners

anchor.surface_text: Section 26A of the Act provides as follows 26A. Procedure in registration of firms.  1  Application may be made to the Income-tax Officer on behalf of any firm, constituted under an instrument of partnership specifying the individual shares of the partners, for registration for the purposes of this Act and of any other enactment for the time being in force relating to income-tax or Super-tax.

concepts.unlisted_description: Procedure in registration of firms requiring instrument specifying individual shares of partners

anchor.surface_text: It should also be noticed that in all the applications for registration made by the assessee-firm under s. 26A of the Act the three partners have been shown to share the profits of the partnership firm equally.

concepts.unlisted_description: Procedure in registration of firms requiring instrument specifying individual shares of partners

anchor.surface_text: Reading the partnership deed as a whole and in the context of the relevant circumstances of the case, we are of the opinion that there was specification of the individual shares of the partners in the profits within the meaning of s. 26A of the Act and the assessee-firm was entitled to registration for the assessment year in question.

concepts.interpretation: Specification of individual shares in profits is satisfied where deed provides equal capital shares and division of net profits/losses amongst all partners equally, read as a whole with surrounding circumstances.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: in the companyduct of the business  b  the partners are entitled to share equally in the profits earned, and shall companytribute equally to the loss

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the assessee the appellate Tribunal referred the following question of law for the determination of the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Act
Rule 2 of the Income-tax Rules framed under s. 59 of the Act requires that the application shall be signed by the partners

Rule 2 of the Income-tax Rules framed under s. 59 of the Act requires that the application shall be signed by the partners  not being minors personally, and prescribes the period within which the application shall be made for the year in question.

Rule 3 provides that the application shall be made in the prescribed form and shall be accompanied by the original instrument of partnership under which the firm is constituted, together with a copy thereof.

concepts.unlisted_description: Form and documents for registration application

anchor.surface_text: It is provided by Rule 4 that if on receipt of the application, the Income- tax Officer is satisfied that there is or was a firm in existence constituted as shown, in the instrument of partnership, and that the application has been properly made, he shall enter in writing at the foot of the instrument or certified copy, as the case may be, a certificate in the prescribed form
By rule 6 the certificate of registration granted under Rule 4 may be renewed for subsequent years.

Section 4 of the Partnership Act defines Partnership as the relation between persons who have agreed to share the profits of a business carried on by all or any of them acting for all Persons who have entered into partnership with one another are called individually part- ners and collectively a firm, and the name under which their business is carried on is called the firm name.

Section 13 of the Partnership Act provides as follows Subject to contract between the partners-  a  a partner is not entitled to receive remuneration for taking part in the conduct of the business  b  the partners are entitled to share equally in the profits earned, and shall contribute equally to the losses sustained by the firm

concepts.unlisted_description: Rights of partners re profit sharing and losses

concepts.interpretation: Partnership deed must be read as a whole, along with relevant circumstances and conduct, to determine if individual shares are specified.

arguments.court_reasoning: Reading the partnership deed as a whole with clauses on equal capital shares and division of net profit/loss amongst all partners, plus conduct in applications and books, specifies individual shares

arguments.claim: Renewal of registration under s. 26A was rightly refused by the Income-tax authorities

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment -dated March 15, 1961, the High Court answered the question in the negative, holding that renewal of registration under s. 26A of the Act was rightly refused by the Income-tax -authorities.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: in the companyduct of the business  b  the partners are entitled to share equally in the profits earned, and shall companytribute equally to the loss

arguments.court_reasoning: Deed read as a whole specifies shares through equal capital allocation and equal division among partners

arguments.claim: On proper construction of the partnership deed clauses, individual shares in profits and losses are specified as equal one-third share each, entitling to registration under s. 26A

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the assessee the argument was put forward that the High Court was in error in holding that the assessee was not entitled to registration under s. 26A of the Act. It was submitted that on a proper construction of the various clauses of the partnership deed dated March 19, 1950 it should have been held that the shares of the three individual persons in the profits and losses were clearly specified, namely, that each partner was allotted an equal one-third share

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ership, and that the application has been properly made, he shall enter in writing at the foot of th

arguments.court_reasoning: The argument of the appellant is well-founded and must be accepted as correct

arguments.claim: Requirements of s. 26A and rules must be strictly complied with to secure benefit of registration like lower tax rates

anchor.surface_text: By securing registration under the Act, the partners of the firm obtain a benefit of lower rates of assessment and no tax is directly charged on the income of the firm. This is an important benefit to which the partners of a registered firm become entitled as a consequence of registration and if it is intended to secure that benefit, the requirements of s. 26A of the Act and the Rules framed under the Act must be strictly complied with

arguments.claim: Partnership deed specifies individual shares in profits as required by s. 26A when read as a whole with equal capital shares, division amongst all partners, and conduct in applications and books

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the argument of the appellant is well-founded and must be accepted as correct. It is evident that under cl. 3 of the partnership deed, the capital allotted to each partner is equal, viz., 5 shares of Rs. 16,000/each in a total capital of Rs. 2,40,000/-. Clause 10 states that after meeting all expenses, interest and other charges, the resulting net profit or loss shall be ascertained and shall be divided amongst all partners.

arguments.claim: Partnership deed must be reasonably construed to determine conformity with s. 26A requirements, as per precedent in Kylasa Sarabhaiah v. CIT

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out by this Court in Kylasa Sarabhaiah v. Commissioner of Income tax, Hyderabad that although the application for registration of a firm under s. 26A of the Act had strictly to be in conformity with the Act and the Rules, in ascertaining whether the application was in conformity with the Rules, the deed of partnership had to be reasonably construed.

holdings.text: Reading the partnership deed as a whole and in the context of the relevant circumstances of the case, we are of the opinion that there was specification of the individual shares of the partners in the profits within the meaning of s. 26A of the Act and the assessee-firm was entitled to registration for the assessment year in question.

anchor.surface_text: Reading the partnership deed as a whole and in the context of the relevant circumstances of the case, we are of the opinion that there was specification of the individual shares of the partners in the profits within the meaning of s. 26A of the Act and the assessee-firm was entitled to registration for the assessment year in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deed clauses 3 (equal capital shares) and 10 (net profit/loss divided amongst all partners) read harmoniously with equal profit sharing in registration applications and books of account satisfy s.26A requirement; consistent with reasonable construction per Kylasa Sarabhaiah precedent.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the argument of the appellant is well-founded and must be accepted as correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant's construction of deed clauses specifying equal one-third shares in profits/losses is correct based on equal capital allocation and division amongst all partners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent requiring reasonable construction of partnership deed to ascertain s.26A conformity applies, as individual shares clear despite no explicit profit percentage clause.

edges.explanation: Argument a1 claims that reading the deed as a whole with equal capital clauses satisfies the s.26A requirement as per concept c8.

Section 26A provides grounds for the holding on registration entitlement.
Concept c8 defining satisfaction of s.26A via equal capital shares and deed provisions grounds the holding h1 that shares were specified on reading the deed as a whole.
Concept c8 on interpretation of s.26A addresses the issue i1 of proper construction of the deed for share specification.
